matched.actualTitle: JWT Signature Not Validated - Privilege Escalation via Forged Token
matched.matchReason: The expected finding describes JWT tokens being decoded without signature verification, allowing user_id manipulation. The actual finding 'JWT Signature Not Validated - Privilege Escalation via Forged Token' directly addresses this vulnerability. The POC demonstrates that the application accepts JWT tokens with invalid signatures and allows modification of claims (user_type to 'admin'), which is the core IDOR vulnerability through JWT manipulation described in the expected finding. The severity and impact align - both describe exploitation of unverified JWT tokens for unauthorized access.

extra.title: Missing CSRF Protection on Logout Endpoint
extra.assessment: New discovery - Not in expected findings. Valid vulnerability demonstrating that the logout endpoint accepts cross-origin requests without CSRF token validation, allowing attackers to force logouts via CSRF attacks.

extra.title: Session Not Properly Invalidated After Logout
extra.assessment: New discovery - Not in expected findings. Critical vulnerability where sessions remain valid on the server after logout, allowing captured session cookies to continue providing access to protected endpoints.

extra.title: JWT Token Missing Expiration Claim (No 'exp' Claim)
extra.assessment: New discovery - Not in expected findings. JWT tokens lack expiration claims, allowing indefinite token validity. Amplifies the impact of JWT signature validation bypass by removing time-based invalidation.

extra.title: Missing SameSite Attribute on Session Cookies
extra.assessment: New discovery - Not in expected findings. Session cookies lack SameSite attribute, enabling CSRF attacks and cross-site cookie transmission.

extra.title: Insecure Direct Object Reference (IDOR) - Unauthorized Password Reset for Arbitrary Users
extra.assessment: New discovery - Not in expected findings. Separate IDOR vulnerability allowing authenticated users to reset passwords for arbitrary users by manipulating the user_id parameter.

extra.title: Unrestricted Brute Force Attack on Password Field - No Rate Limiting
extra.assessment: New discovery - Not in expected findings. Password endpoint accepts unlimited rapid attempts (172.9 req/sec) without rate limiting, account lockout, or CAPTCHA protection.

extra.title: Information Disclosure - User ID Exposed in Password Form HTML
extra.assessment: New discovery - Not in expected findings. Sensitive user_id values are exposed in hidden form fields, allowing unauthenticated user enumeration and IDOR attack facilitation.

extra.title: Sensitive JWT Token (auth_token) Missing HttpOnly Flag - XSS Vulnerability
extra.assessment: New discovery - Not in expected findings. Authentication JWT tokens lack HttpOnly flag, making them accessible to JavaScript and allowing XSS attacks to steal authentication tokens.

extra.title: IDOR with Empty Password Acceptance - Trivial Account Takeover
extra.assessment: New discovery - Not in expected findings. Critical combination of IDOR and input validation bypass allowing attackers to set arbitrary users' passwords to empty strings, enabling trivial account takeover.

extra.title: Test Account (test:test) Still Enabled in Production
extra.location: HTML source code with TODO comment; user database
extra.assessment: New discovery - Not in expected findings. Hardcoded test credentials are fully functional in production, allowing any attacker to gain authenticated access to the system.

extra.title: Missing CSRF Protection on Login Form
extra.assessment: New discovery - Not in expected findings. Login endpoint lacks CSRF token validation, allowing cross-origin login attempts and enabling username enumeration via CSRF.

extra.title: Cross-Site Request Forgery (CSRF) on Password Reset Endpoint
extra.assessment: New discovery - Not in expected findings. Password reset endpoint vulnerable to CSRF attacks, allowing attackers to silently change user passwords without user knowledge or consent.

extra.title: User Enumeration via /password/{username} Endpoint - Response Differentiation
extra.assessment: New discovery - Not in expected findings. Endpoint returns different HTTP responses for valid (200) vs invalid (302) usernames, enabling systematic username enumeration.

extra.title: User Enumeration via Main Login Endpoint - Inconsistent Response Behavior
extra.assessment: New discovery - Not in expected findings. Login endpoint returns HTTP 302 for valid usernames but HTTP 200 for invalid usernames, enabling username enumeration through response code analysis.
